extra.message: This tag is missing an 'integrity' subresource integrity attribute. The 'integrity' attribute allows for the browser to verify that externally hosted files (for example from a CDN) are delivered without unexpected manipulation. Without this attribute, if an attacker can modify the externally hosted resource, this could lead to XSS and other types of attacks. To prevent this, include the base64-encoded cryptographic hash of the resource (file) youâ€™re telling the browser to fetch in the 'integrity' attribute for all externally hosted files.

extra.message: Detected data rendered directly to the end user via 'HttpResponse' or a similar object. This bypasses Django's built-in cross-site scripting (XSS) defenses and could result in an XSS vulnerability. Use Django's template engine to safely render HTML.

cwe: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
metadata.license: Semgrep Rules License v1.0. For more details, visit semgrep.dev/legal/rules-license

extra.message: Detected the use of exec(). exec() can be dangerous if used to evaluate dynamic content. If this content can be input from outside the program, this may be a code injection vulnerability. Ensure evaluated content is not definable by external sources.

cwe: CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')

extra.message: Untrusted user input in `importlib.import_module()` function allows an attacker to load arbitrary code. Avoid dynamic values in `importlib.import_module()` or use a whitelist to prevent running untrusted code.

cwe: CWE-706: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference
metadata.license: Semgrep Rules License v1.0. For more details, visit semgrep.dev/legal/rules-license

extra.message: The 'ssl' module disables insecure cipher suites by default. Therefore, use of 'set_ciphers()' should only be used when you have very specialized requirements. Otherwise, you risk lowering the security of the SSL channel.
